articles.headline: For Europe, an Unpleasant Question: Confront Trump or Avoid a Costly Trade War
articles.snippet: As the European Union faces a potential trade war with the United States, its resolve is likely to be tested by differing interests within the bloc.
articles.abstract: As the European Union faces a potential trade war with the United States, its resolve is likely to be tested by differing interests within the bloc.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROME — For Europe, the first move was easy. Officials swiftly announced plans to strike back with retaliatory measures against President Trump’s tariffs on steel and aluminum while vowing a legal challenge.

articles.headline: Trump Announces Summit Meeting With Kim Jong-un Is Back On
articles.snippet: The head-spinning diplomatic reversal came as President Trump welcomed North Korea’s former intelligence chief to a rare meeting at the White House.
articles.abstract: The head-spinning diplomatic reversal came as President Trump welcomed North Korea’s former intelligence chief to a rare meeting at the White House.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump will fly to Singapore this month after all for a landmark summit meeting with North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un, but he now anticipates a more drawn-out negotiation than once envisioned and indicated that he will stop increasing pressure on the regime while talks proceed.

articles.headline: Google Will Not Renew Pentagon Contract That Upset Employees
articles.snippet: Diane Greene, the head of Google’s Cloud business, is said to have told employees that it was backing away from the A.I. work with the military.
articles.abstract: Diane Greene, the head of Google’s Cloud business, is said to have told employees that it was backing away from the A.I. work with the military.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Google, hoping to head off a rebellion by employees upset that the technology they were working on could be used for lethal purposes, will not renew a contract with the Pentagon for artificial intelligence work when a current deal expires next year.
articles.byline: By Daisuke Wakabayashi and Scott Shane

articles.headline: 3 Women Who Had Encounters With Harvey Weinstein Question Lawyer’s Motives
articles.snippet: Three women say they were led to believe the film mogul Harvey Weinstein’s criminal defense firm wanted to represent them in a lawsuit against the disgraced film producer.
articles.abstract: Three women say they were led to believe the film mogul Harvey Weinstein’s criminal defense firm wanted to represent them in a lawsuit against the disgraced film producer.
articles.lead_paragraph: When it emerged in November that the film mogul Harvey Weinstein had hired one of Manhattan’s top criminal defense lawyers amid rape allegations, Daniela Unruh was shocked.
articles.byline: By Rachel Abrams and Matthew Goldstein

articles.headline: The Jobs Recovery: A Longer View
articles.snippet: With the monthly job-creation streak continuing to set records, the data shed light both on the rebound from the recession and on what’s left to be desired.
articles.abstract: With the monthly job-creation streak continuing to set records, the data shed light both on the rebound from the recession and on what’s left to be desired.
articles.lead_paragraph: Friday’s jobs report was a blockbuster: Job growth rebounded after a recent dip, and the unemployment rate fell to a nearly two-decade low. But it’s worth taking a step back and putting the latest numbers in some longer-run context.

articles.headline: Hello, You Must Be Going: Hulu Parts With a Top Executive
articles.snippet: Last summer, Joel Stillerman joined the streaming platform as its first chief content officer. Now he’s out, and the job will not be refilled.
articles.abstract: Last summer, Joel Stillerman joined the streaming platform as its first chief content officer. Now he’s out, and the job will not be refilled.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last summer, the executive Joel Stillerman started work at Hulu as its first-ever chief content officer. On Friday, the streaming platform announced that he was out.

articles.headline: Tech Was Supposed to Get Political. It’s Hanging Back in This Election.
articles.snippet: While voters get ready for California’s primary on June 5, Silicon Valley’s tech community — which had been politically outspoken — has tried to stay largely under the radar.
articles.abstract: While voters get ready for California’s primary on June 5, Silicon Valley’s tech community — which had been politically outspoken — has tried to stay largely under the radar.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Over the last decade, this has become the tech industry’s hometown.

articles.headline: Getting Down Payment Help Now. Sharing Home’s Gain (or Loss) Later.
articles.snippet: A small but growing number of people are cobbling together what they need to get a substantial down payment by asking an outside investor to put down part of the money.
articles.abstract: A small but growing number of people are cobbling together what they need to get a substantial down payment by asking an outside investor to put down part of the money.
articles.lead_paragraph: For aspiring homeowners, coming up with a healthy down payment has long been the biggest obstacle to owning a home.

articles.headline: How Marc Jacobs Fell Out of Fashion
articles.snippet: In recent years, Mr. Jacobs has left Louis Vuitton, shrunk his own business, shut dozens of stores and lost his longtime business partner. And what’s happening with that I.P.O.?
articles.abstract: In recent years, Mr. Jacobs has left Louis Vuitton, shrunk his own business, shut dozens of stores and lost his longtime business partner. And what’s happening with that I.P.O.?
articles.lead_paragraph: Monday night, when some of fashion’s biggest names gather at the Brooklyn Museum for the annual Council of Fashion Designers of America awards — often called the Oscars of the fashion world — a familiar figure will again be celebrated: Marc Jacobs. He is nominated for the group’s top award, women’s wear designer of the year, as he has been every year since 2013, winning in 2016. He was awarded the group’s Lifetime Achievement Award in 2011.

articles.headline: A Courtside View of Scott Pruitt’s Cozy Ties With a Billionaire Coal Baron
articles.snippet: The E.P.A. chief, who has reversed Obama-era rules on coal mining, enjoyed a superfan experience at a University of Kentucky basketball game — courtesy of an industry executive.
articles.abstract: The E.P.A. chief, who has reversed Obama-era rules on coal mining, enjoyed a superfan experience at a University of Kentucky basketball game — courtesy of an industry executive.
articles.lead_paragraph: LEXINGTON, Ky. — It was one of the biggest games of the University of Kentucky basketball season, and Scott Pruitt had scored two of the best seats in the arena: a few feet from the action, in a section reserved for season-ticket holders who had donated at least $1 million to the university.
articles.byline: By Steve Eder, Hiroko Tabuchi and Eric Lipton

articles.headline: California Governor’s Race Forces Candidates to Face the Past
articles.snippet: Gavin Newsom and Antonio Villaraigosa, the leading Democratic contenders in Tuesday’s primary must contend with Jerry Brown’s long shadow and voters’ memories of past indiscretions.
articles.abstract: Gavin Newsom and Antonio Villaraigosa, the leading Democratic contenders in Tuesday’s primary must contend with Jerry Brown’s long shadow and voters’ memories of past indiscretions.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sign up for California Today for the latest news on the June 5 primary and more here.
articles.byline: By Adam Nagourney, Sydney Ember and Alexander Burns

articles.headline: Within Trump’s Trade Factions, Nations Look for a Friendly Face
articles.snippet: Divisions and reversals on trade under President Trump have flummoxed U.S. allies and rivals, who are courting whichever advisers they think will listen.
articles.abstract: Divisions and reversals on trade under President Trump have flummoxed U.S. allies and rivals, who are courting whichever advisers they think will listen.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — As the United States challenges Europe, China, Canada, Mexico and much of the rest of the world over trade, deep factionalism within the Trump administration has flummoxed both American allies and rivals. The White House strikes a conciliatory tone one day and a militant one the next, often depending on which Trump advisers are in favor.

articles.headline: In Vancouver, a Housing Frenzy That Even Owners Want to End
articles.snippet: Facing a crisis of affordability, officials are trying to reduce real estate demand through a package of tax measures, some aimed at foreign buyers.
articles.abstract: Facing a crisis of affordability, officials are trying to reduce real estate demand through a package of tax measures, some aimed at foreign buyers.
articles.lead_paragraph: VANCOUVER, British Columbia — Between multimillion-dollar tear-downs, blocks full of backyard cottages and towering condominiums that are sold and resold several times before they are even built, there is no shortage of anecdotes about this city’s housing frenzy.

articles.headline: Trump Veers to a Korea Plan That Echoes Failures of the Past
articles.snippet: President Trump has vowed not to repeat the errors of his predecessors, but his apparent softening on North Korea resembles approaches taken by Bill Clinton and George W. Bush.
articles.abstract: President Trump has vowed not to repeat the errors of his predecessors, but his apparent softening on North Korea resembles approaches taken by Bill Clinton and George W. Bush.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump never tires of pointing out that his predecessors left him the “mess” of a nuclear-armed North Korea — a legacy of errors he vows not to repeat.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: Trump’s Lawyers, in Confidential Memo, Argue to Head Off a Historic Subpoena
articles.snippet: The legal memo takes an expansive view on the president’s authority. Lawyers argued that, as president, Mr. Trump has the power to end investigations.
articles.abstract: The legal memo takes an expansive view on the president’s authority. Lawyers argued that, as president, Mr. Trump has the power to end investigations.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s lawyers have for months quietly waged a campaign to keep the special counsel from trying to force him to answer questions in the investigation into whether he obstructed justice, asserting that he cannot be compelled to testify and arguing in a confidential letter that he could not possibly have committed obstruction because he has unfettered authority over all federal investigations.
articles.byline: By Michael S. Schmidt, Maggie Haberman, Charlie Savage and Matt Apuzzo

articles.headline: When Guns Are Sold Illegally, A.T.F. Is Lenient on Punishment
articles.snippet: Regulators are wary of punishing gun stores that break the law, a review of internal inspection reports and interviews with officials shows.
articles.abstract: Regulators are wary of punishing gun stores that break the law, a review of internal inspection reports and interviews with officials shows.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As they inspect the nation’s gun stores, federal investigators regularly find violations of the law, ranging from minor record-keeping errors to illegal sales of firearms. In the most serious cases, like a sale of a gun to a prohibited buyer, inspectors often recommend that gun dealers lose their licenses.

articles.headline: How Mnuchin Keeps a Steady Grip in a Tug of War on Trade
articles.snippet: The Treasury secretary, Steven Mnuchin, has managed to stay in President Trump’s good graces while advocating a more free-trade approach, but that balancing act is showing signs of strain.
articles.abstract: The Treasury secretary, Steven Mnuchin, has managed to stay in President Trump’s good graces while advocating a more free-trade approach, but that balancing act is showing signs of strain.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Two weeks ago, Steven Mnuchin, the Treasury secretary, declared that the trade war with China was “on hold” and that the United States would temporarily holster its tariffs. The reassuring comments calmed markets and raised hopes that Mr. Mnuchin, one of President Trump’s most enduring and trusted advisers, was winning the internal trade battle that has gripped the White House.

articles.headline: Democrats Hope Asian-American Influx Will Help Turn Orange County Blue
articles.snippet: The demographics are evolving fast in the once reliably Republican suburbs of Southern California, but what that will mean at the ballot box remains a big question mark for the midterms.
articles.abstract: The demographics are evolving fast in the once reliably Republican suburbs of Southern California, but what that will mean at the ballot box remains a big question mark for the midterms.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sign up for our California Today newsletter.

articles.headline: I, Sy: Seymour Hersh’s Memoir of a Life Making the Mighty Sweat
articles.snippet: In “Reporter,” Mr. Hersh revisits his coverage of Vietnam, Nixon and Bin Laden. “I will happily permit history to be the judge of my recent work,” he said.
articles.abstract: In “Reporter,” Mr. Hersh revisits his coverage of Vietnam, Nixon and Bin Laden. “I will happily permit history to be the judge of my recent work,” he said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Seymour M. Hersh didn’t even want to write a memoir.

articles.headline: Facebook Tried to Rein In Fake Ads. It Fell Short in a California Race.
articles.snippet: Measures to prevent election interference remain spotty, as shown in the Fourth Congressional District’s Democratic primary.
articles.abstract: Measures to prevent election interference remain spotty, as shown in the Fourth Congressional District’s Democratic primary.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Regina Bateson had just finished an Easter egg hunt with her children on April 1 when her phone started buzzing. Take a look at Facebook, messages from her friends and colleagues urged.

articles.headline: Facebook Gave Device Makers Deep Access to Data on Users and Friends
articles.snippet: The company formed data-sharing partnerships with Apple, Samsung and dozens of other device makers, raising new concerns about its privacy protections.
articles.abstract: The company formed data-sharing partnerships with Apple, Samsung and dozens of other device makers, raising new concerns about its privacy protections.
articles.lead_paragraph: The company formed data-sharing partnerships with Apple, Samsung and dozens of other device makers, raising new concerns about its privacy protections.
articles.byline: By Gabriel J.X. Dance, Nicholas Confessore and Michael LaForgia

articles.headline: Microsoft Buys GitHub for $7.5 Billion, Moving to Grow in Coding’s New Era
articles.snippet: The acquisition of the software development company is meant to help Microsoft gain ground in the area of so-called cloud computing.
articles.abstract: The acquisition of the software development company is meant to help Microsoft gain ground in the area of so-called cloud computing.
articles.lead_paragraph: Microsoft, fully embracing a model it once saw as a threat, said on Monday that it was buying GitHub, an open software platform used by 28 million programmers, for $7.5 billion.

articles.headline: In Narrow Decision, Supreme Court Sides With Baker Who Turned Away Gay Couple
articles.snippet: The court passed on an opportunity to either bolster the right to same-sex marriage or explain how far the government can go in regulating businesses run on religious principles.
articles.abstract: The court passed on an opportunity to either bolster the right to same-sex marriage or explain how far the government can go in regulating businesses run on religious principles.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday ruled in favor of a Colorado baker who had refused to create a wedding cake for a gay couple. The court’s decision was narrow, and it left open the larger question of whether a business can discriminate against gay men and lesbians based on rights protected by the First Amendment.

articles.headline: Safe in Hungary, Viktor Orban Pushes His Message Across Europe
articles.snippet: Allies of Mr. Orban, Hungary’s far-right leader, are buying media outlets across Central and Eastern Europe, extending his influence.
articles.abstract: Allies of Mr. Orban, Hungary’s far-right leader, are buying media outlets across Central and Eastern Europe, extending his influence.
articles.lead_paragraph: LJUBLJANA, Slovenia — By finishing first in national elections in Slovenia on Sunday, the hard-liner Janez Jansa has ridden a right-wing populist wave into power in yet another European country. Among those he can thank is Viktor Orban, the Hungarian prime minister, who campaigned at his side and darkly warned that the election was about “the survival of the Slovenian nation.”
